description.summary: A chimeric Japanese yokai with multiple animal parts, famous for bringing misfortune and illness. Best known from the Tale of the Heike where it plagued Emperor Konoe before being slain by warrior Minamoto no Yorimasa.
description.full: The Nue is one of Japan's most fearsome yokai, described as a chimeric creature combining parts from multiple animals. Most commonly depicted with a monkey's head, tanuki (raccoon dog) body, tiger's limbs, and a snake for a tail. Some versions describe it as having the face of a monkey, body of a tiger, snake tail, and the voice of a white thrush bird. The Nue appears as a black cloud and brings supernatural illness, nightmares, and misfortune. Its most famous appearance was during the Heian period when it caused Emperor Konoe's mysterious illness in the 12th century, until the legendary warrior Minamoto no Yorimasa shot it down. The creature symbolizes chaos, supernatural pestilence, and ominous portents in Japanese folklore.

etymology.origin: From Japanese folklore, first appearing in written records during the Heian period (794-1185). Prominently featured in The Tale of the Heike (Heike Monogatari).
etymology.meaning: The name 'nue' originally referred to a type of bird (possibly a white-rumped swift or thrush) known for its eerie cry

history.modern_era: The Nue remains a popular figure in Japanese culture, appearing in yokai collections, video games (particularly the Final Fantasy series), anime, and manga. It symbolizes the chimeric and chaotic nature of supernatural threats.

notable.name: Emperor Konoe's Affliction
notable.description: A black cloud appeared nightly above the Imperial Palace, and Emperor Konoe fell mysteriously ill with terrible nightmares. The legendary warrior Minamoto no Yorimasa was summoned. On a dark night, he shot an arrow into the black cloud. The Nue fell to earth, revealing its chimeric form. The Emperor's illness immediately ceased. The creature's body was placed in a boat and sent down the river.
